instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A spillage of liquid No power no charge
threads.message:
hi,
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A  liquid won't turn on after spillage

<RESISTOR>R3105</RESISTOR> not in place Does this prevent opening? 

F3000 pin1-2= 5.1 Voltage
F3001=No voltage

<DIODE>D6902</DIODE>= 
pin 1 5.1 Voltage /  pin 2 = No Voltage / pin 3 = 4.7 Voltage

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A spillage of liquid No power no charge
threads.message:
Only one input fuse gets voltage at time; depending where the charger is connected.
<RESISTOR>R3105</RESISTOR> must be soldered.

threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C7256</CAPACITOR> is near the CPU power supply; is not a good place for liquid spill.
CPU could be dead now.

Post diode mode to ground at F7000.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A spillage of liquid No power no charge
threads.message:
You have a problem on UB300/400 area.
Be sure all surrounding resistors are good.
Check UB090 solders/traces and related resistors.

threads.message: CB413 pin 1 is short circuited, so I removed the CB413 and DZB552 on the same line. But cb413 pin 1 is still short circuited, however RB302 pin 1 is short circuited. Should I replace UB300 and UB400?

Once the chips are removed, check if short is gone; before resolder new one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A spillage of liquid No power no charge
threads.message:
I Removed the UB300 and UB400. There is no short circuit on CB413 pin1. But RB302 pin1 is shorted. When I checked from the schematic, I saw that the value of RB302 was 0. So it is normal to show a short circuit with the ground. I removed the UB300 in vain. I understand you didn't check. It escaped my notice.

2.
When I look at the schematic, it says <RESISTOR>R3033</RESISTOR> is not in place. But <RESISTOR>R3033</RESISTOR> is in place and shows short circuit. the diagram shows the value as 100k. I did not understand this situation. Is it normal for it to be short circuited or should I replace it with another 100k resistor? I added the pictures about it
 Also, when UB300 and UB400 are not in place, will the device turn on via other usb? Or do they absolutely have to be?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A spillage of liquid No power no charge
threads.message:
All <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips must be placed on the board.

Compare <RESISTOR>R3033</RESISTOR>/34 and their lines to ground in diode mode.

threads.message: I guess you didn't read what I wrote. The value of <RESISTOR>R3033</RESISTOR>/34 appears as 100k and no stuff in the diagram, but there are these parts on the motherboard and when I measure it, the values are 0 ohms. When I remove the <RESISTOR>R3033</RESISTOR>/34 and measure its 1st pin with ground, there is no short circuit. 0.504 shows up in diode mode. Is the value of these resistors really 0 or should it be 100k as written in the diagram?

Did YOU read what you've wrote?

I don't have 00928 board on hand now.
But I can confirm with 00281; the same resistors are used for the same signals.
<RESISTOR>R3033</RESISTOR> is soldered and has 0 ohm; also <RESISTOR>R3034</RESISTOR>.

BTW, <RESISTOR>R3035</RESISTOR>/36 can't be present in this case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A spillage of liquid No power no charge
threads.message:
That means you still have problems in UB300/400 area.
Inspect the terminals of USB-C connector.
Compare diode mode to ground readings on different points between left/right ports.
Be sure UB090 has good solders/traces and surrounding resistors OK.

Do you get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage when connect the battery?
Try with known good battery.
All USB-C ports still remain on 5V then?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A spillage of liquid No power no charge
threads.message: does this device work without batteries?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A spillage of liquid No power no charge
threads.message:
It should get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at least, without battery.
Testing with battery in this case may help to see if there is other problem, apart of USB-C area.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A spillage of liquid No power no charge
threads.message:
F7000= <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> =no voltage 

no voltage with or without battery

I read 5 volts on FB201, shouldn't it be 20 volts here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A spillage of liquid No power no charge
threads.message:
FB200/1 will get 20V only after correct communication between SMC and charger.

No voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> means there is other problem, apart of USB-C area.
I supposed the battery data cable was also connected and battery still holds some charge.

What should I check between SMC and charger

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A spillage of liquid No power no charge
threads.message:
Seems that your board suffered more damage than expected; because of liquid spill.
You still have problems on UB300/400 area, but also somewhere else.
Possibly SMC got bad, if you don't get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at all; nor even with battery connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A spillage of liquid No power no charge
threads.message:
I understand that the absence of <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> has nothing to do with CBs. you say <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> should be output anyway, but is this a definite SMC problem?
in a similar problem, smc and 4xCB were changed, the problem was not resolved

[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-5v-looping-one-side-only.59983/[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A spillage of liquid No power no charge
threads.message:
Changing the chips can't assure the board repair.
Broken traces, bad solders, corroded passive components (caps, resistors, coils), can block the correct communication.
Also accumulated crap under BGA chips can cause leakage between balls.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A spillage of liquid No power no charge
threads.message:
There was corrosion in the <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> area. And the <RESISTOR>R2890</RESISTOR> was not in place. I had cleaned that area before and replaced the <RESISTOR>R2890</RESISTOR>. Could the <RESISTOR>R2890</RESISTOR> be broken?

[MEDIA=youtube]vXAK2l1oMZM:820[/MEDIA]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A spillage of liquid No power no charge
threads.message:
Replace corroded resistors, check traces and solders; for <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> and also UB090.
You can compare diode mode readings between both chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A spillage of liquid No power no charge
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Isn't the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> considered defective because it has no voltage?

I injected voltage into the f7000 from the outside. There is no short circuit. no hot parts

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A spillage of liquid No power no charge
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> requires correct communication with SMC, to generate correct <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage.

Injecting voltage into a power rail where you don't have short, or incorrect resistance to ground, doesn't help at all.
Did you test the board with known good battery (holding some charge)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A spillage of liquid No power no charge
threads.message:
It has a 5 volt cycle

I noticed that the capacitor I just marked has a short circuit with ground. I can't see this field in boardview.[ATTACH type="full"]60332[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A spillage of liquid No power no charge
threads.message:
I think that was already mentioned on the forum as being normal.
This is one of the reasons I said the people to read EACH forum thread and take notes when important information appears!

In case of 5V cycle, you should check for short, or low value on all secondary power rails.
However, I'm afraid you have a lost caused here, because of liquid damage...
